title: Isaac's Marriage
shortSummary: Genesis 24 recounts Abraham’s servant’s mission to find a wife for Isaac, demonstrating God’s providence and faithfulness in guiding His people. The chapter highlights prayer, obedience, and divine guidance in the fulfillment of God’s promises to Abraham’s family.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch who sends his servant to find a wife for his son Isaac, emphasizing faithfulness to God's covenant.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham’s Servant
keyCharacters.description: The trusted servant tasked with finding a wife for Isaac, who prays for God’s guidance and acts with faith and wisdom.

keyCharacters.name: Rebekah
keyCharacters.description: The woman chosen by God’s providence to be Isaac’s wife, noted for her kindness and willingness to obey.

keyCharacters.name: Laban
keyCharacters.description: Rebekah’s brother who welcomes Abraham’s servant and consents to the marriage arrangement.

keyCharacters.name: Bethuel
keyCharacters.description: Rebekah’s father, who along with Laban, acknowledges God’s hand in the marriage proposal.

definitions.term: Put thy hand under my thigh
definitions.definition: An ancient oath-taking gesture symbolizing a solemn vow, often associated with the covenant of inheritance.
The region between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, identified here as the homeland of Abraham’s relatives.
A unit of weight and currency in ancient Israel, used here to describe the value of gold jewelry given to Rebekah.
A messenger of God; in this chapter, the servant trusts that God will send His angel to guide the mission.

outline.heading: Abraham’s Charge to His Servant
outline.description: Abraham, advanced in age, commands his servant to swear an oath not to take a wife for Isaac from the Canaanites but from his own kin, emphasizing faithfulness to God’s covenant promises.

outline.heading: The Servant’s Prayer and Divine Guidance
outline.description: The servant travels to Nahor’s city, prays for God’s guidance, and receives a clear sign through Rebekah’s kindness at the well, confirming God’s providential leading.

outline.heading: Negotiation and Consent for the Marriage
outline.description: Rebekah’s family recognizes God’s hand in the matter and consents to the marriage, affirming the servant’s mission as divinely ordained.

outline.heading: Rebekah’s Departure and Meeting Isaac
outline.description: Rebekah agrees to leave with the servant, is blessed by her family, and upon arrival, meets Isaac, who takes her as his wife, bringing comfort after Sarah’s death.

application: Trust God’s providence in important decisions and seek His guidance through prayer as the servant did.
Obey God’s commands faithfully, even when they require difficult or unfamiliar actions, like Abraham’s servant traveling far to find a wife.
Demonstrate kindness and hospitality as Rebekah did, reflecting God’s love in practical ways.
Recognize and rejoice in God’s faithfulness to His promises, encouraging perseverance in faith.

keyVerses.text: And he said, O LORD God of my master Abraham, I pray thee, send me good speed this day, and shew kindness unto my master Abraham.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the servant’s reliance on prayer and God’s kindness as essential for success.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Blessed be the LORD God of my master Abraham, who hath not left destitute my master of his mercy and his truth: I being in the way, the LORD led me to the house of my master's brethren.
keyVerses.significance: It expresses gratitude for God’s faithfulness and guidance throughout the servant’s journey.

keyVerses.text: And they called Rebekah, and said unto her, Wilt thou go with this man? And she said, I will go.
keyVerses.significance: Rebekah’s willing obedience exemplifies trust in God’s plan and readiness to follow His leading.

keyVerses.text: And Isaac brought her into his mother Sarah's tent, and took Rebekah, and she became his wife; and he loved her: and Isaac was comforted after his mother's death.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the fulfillment of God’s promise and the comfort found in His provision.
